section.name: FREEDOM: Freedom: What is it, how to measure it, how it affects policy making
PHILOS, POLITICS & ECON: Making Sense of Medernity
PHILOS, POLITICS & ECON: The Psychology of Societal Problems

comments:
This Capstone seminar explores the topic of social psychology. Since its beginnings, social psychology has investigated interpersonal judgment, uncovering many biases in the way people evaluate other people and themselves. More recently, cognitive psychologists have also started to develop theories of how people understand and judge other people. This class is at the crossroad of these two traditions, looking into cognitive models of how people judge other people, and how people use similar mechanisms to judge themselves. It is intended to offer the advanced student a quasi-graduate environment where they are exposed to the frontiers of research on the subject, while also providing them with a comprehensive overview of the topic.

Students described this course as “great” and “very well paced,” and they reported that it “really expanded their knowledge.” The material itself was described as “extremely interesting,” and the lectures were described as “enjoyable;” however, students’ class presentations were “sometimes quite boring and easy to lose focus on.” Several students regretted that the class did not incorporate discussion and was confined mostly to lecturing.

Professor Mercier was described as “excellent,” and students appreciated that he put a lot of effort into preparing each lecture. Students also commended his “great ability” to clarify difficult concepts and “convey complex information in a very clear manner.” One complaint students had was that they did not receive feedback about work and grades throughout the semester, which made it difficult to know how they should improve their work in their final paper.

This course is an integrative senior seminar for the PPE major, only open to others by departmental permission. It is the highest-level class offered for PPE majors. Students reported that there was “generally too much reading assigned each week,” which resulted in many students failing to complete the readings. Many papers were required for this course, including a final paper worth the majority of each student’s grade. Many students commented about the lack of feedback they received throughout the semester in terms of grades and quality of work and expressed concern about not knowing what to expect for their final grades. Some students also noted that they felt that there was not enough explanation about the requirements or expectations for their projects and paper.
